. Let's use the latest godep in vendor mode rather than bmiz/vendor. The new Godep still stores the SHAs which is important for being able to reconstruct GOPATH when updating packages or adding siblings.
Example:
- Developer A vendors github.com/foo/bar/baz at SHA 123456, commits, and pushes
- Developer B wants to vendor github.com/foo/bar/qux but doesn't know which SHA its sibling was committed using unless there is some sort of manifest.
This scenario will happen quite often with things like aws-sdk-go when we start using a new service.

``` shell
$ cat start-mode1.sh
!/bin/bash
term-new-window() { ... }
term-new-tab() { ... }
term-new-window
term-new-tab "cd ~/src/a1 && convox start --internal"
term-new-tab "cd ~/src/a2 && convox start --internal --link a1"

```

That is the case.
We have always been able to update the runtime attribute of Lambda, and
already did so for things like the lifecycle handler in
https://github.com/convox/rack/pull/1519/files.
We haven't been able to update the runtime attribute of CF custom handlers
due to a CloudFormation limitation. That limitation of CF is now gone in
some regions.
When it is gone in every region we can remove the mapping and conditional
logic altogether, and hardcode 'nodejs4.3' for all lambda functions, custom
topics and otherwise.

I would be amenable to a --no-build-instance flag to convox install. can move this to the _linux specific file since it's linux specific. best way to read a file contents in go is
data, err := ioutil.ReadFile("/etc/os-release"). I would probably break this into two functions, sort of like this pseudocode
```
var reAttributeMatcher = regexp.MustCompile("...")  (substitute appropriate regex here, see https://golang.org/pkg/regexp/)
func linuxReleaseAttributes() (map[string]string, error) {
  attrs := map[string]string{}
  data = read(/etc/os-release)
  s := bufio.NewScanner(bytes.NewReader(data))
  for s.Scan() {
    if m := reAttributeMatcher.FindStringSubmatch(s.Text()); len(m) >= 2 {
     attrs[m[0]] = m[1]
    }
  }
}
func linuxRelease() (string, error) {
  attrs, err := linuxReleaseAttributes()
  if err return err
  return fmt.Sprintf("%s-%s", attrs["NAME"], attrs["VERSION_ID"])
}. dont need the extra space at the beginning of functions. This ToLower is likely going to conflict with looking for NAME and VERSION_ID in the function below. The goal here is to make convox start work when you have more than one internal load balancer listening on the same port.
This isn't a problem in production because each process type gets its own ELB.
It was broken with convox start because when we did the port mapping we'd just use a host port that matched the internal port. This caused port conflicts on the host if you had more than one process using the same internal port.
The solution here (as I understand it) was to use random host ports with convox start to avoid conflicts.

. http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonECS/latest/developerguide/task_definition_parameters.html
The Task Definition CPU setting is fairly arbitrary on how it affects running containers. It is not required to set at all, and only guides soft guarantees in the kernel and cgroups about how a container runs. What happens in effect is that all running containers compete to use the CPU they need irregardless of what this might set.
So this patch only tweaks how we can account for CPU usage. Before this patch we were using a constant number for all container tasks. Now we set the number proportional to the memory, which is commonly scaled up or down.

--private adds a 2nd network but retains the public network for internet-facing ELBs.
Rack

[ ] --private flag creates an additional 3 private subnets, gateways and gateway attachments. Default values are 10.0.4.0/24, 10.0.5.0/24, 10.0.6.0/24
[ ] --subnet{0,1,2}-private-cidr option to customize private subnets values
[ ] --private flag creates 3 NAT gateways, routes, and elastic IPs 
[ ] when --private, instances and convox ELB are placed in the private subnet

Apps

[ ] create and set Private Yes/No Parameter on app template
[ ] always create ELB in public subnet if service port mapping indicates public (80:80)
[ ] conditionally create ELB in private subnet if service port mapping indicates private (80) and  Private=Yes

Docs

[ ] document VPC peering
[ ] document VPN access
[ ] document Grid access?

. You can also set the proper LINK_ variables in docker-compose.yml, when you don't want to change the image. So you could use the offical _/redis like this:
```
web:
  build: .
  command: node server.js
  environment:
    - REDIS_URL
  ports:
    - 80:8080
  links:
    - redis
worker:
  command: node worker.js
  environment:
    - REDIS_URL
  build: .
  links:
    - redis
redis:
  image: redis
  environment:
    - LINK_USERNAME=
    - LINK_SCHEME=redis
    - LINK_PATH=0
    - LINK_PASSWORD=
  ports:
    - 6379
```
However ideally it's baked into the image, as convox/redis does here:
https://github.com/convox/redis/blob/master/Dockerfile#L10-L13

. Some pointers for the Travis test failures...
controllers/apps_test.go uses a testing strategy reminiscent of the ruby VCR gem. The client talks to a mock HTTP server that has expectations around a series of requests coming in and responses that they return.
Your patch has changed the expected request/response cycles in the controllers/apps_test.go TestAppCreate and TestAppShowWithAppNotFound tests.
The TestAppShowWithAppNotFound "No cycles remaining to replay." error means that GET http://convox/apps/bar call now makes one or more additional AWS HTTP calls that the test harness is not expecting.
Look at the DescribeStackNotFound function in test/aws_cycles.go. That has a single mock CloudFormation call that returns a 'does not exist' 400 for the stack.
With your changes, it looks like we now expect 2 CloudFormation calls for the two different stack name format lookups.
The TestAppCreate error is similar:
Request does not match next cycle.
CYCLE REQUEST:
RequestURI: /
Operation: 
Body: /^Action=CreateStack/
ACTUAL REQUEST:
RequestURI: /
Operation: 
Body: Action=DescribeStacks&StackName=application&Version=2010-05-15
Your change now performs a CF DescribeStacks call first, where before it was expecting a CF CreateStack first.
. So to fix these tests, you will end up adding at least one more cycle to the aws := test.StubAws() setup in the TestAppShowWithAppNotFound and TestAppCreate test methods.

+package models_test

+
+func TestAppStackName(t *testing.T) {
+       // unbound app (no rack prefix, no Name tag)

+               Name: "httpd",

+                       "System": "convox",

Correct. The reason is that preserving ELB config and names is critical to preserve CNames and any extra DNS for existing apps. There are existing backflips around detecting a "primary process" to preserve the oldest ELB name convention.
As for format, I like: elbName = sprintf("%s-%s", trunc(processName, 23), trunc(sha256(stackName), 7))
My argument against a RandomHexDigest app Parameter is that someone could change it and that would cause all the ELBs to get recreated, which would violate the critical nature of ELB names as stated above.
Stack name is immutable over the life of an app. Process name is the logical id for any process type, so if that changes it implies its ok to change the ELB name.
. While I'm aware of scope creep, the primary process ELB logic has a pretty bad side effect: https://github.com/convox/rack/issues/354
We can use this as an opportunity to unwind that too. Apps under this new scheme do not need any special primary process naming logic.

. Another question... Certain sets of options parse just fine but eventually end up in a rolled back stack. For example with redis:
$ convox services create redis --automatic-failover-enabled

Automatic failover is not supported for T1 and T2 cache node types.

Should the CLI validate these inputs? Or should the template have conditional logic around parameters like AutomaticFailoverEnabled?
. Yes, we're leaning on CF for everything. It does the initial parameter validation very well. The new errors I saw are more subtle in that the parameters validate, and the stack creation starts, but it fails after a minute into a rollback state.

```
$ convox services create redis --multi-az
Creating redis-4794 (redis: multi-az="true")... ERROR: Options: [MultiAZ] are not supported by this service
$ convox services create redis --automatic-failover-enabled
Creating redis-4799 (redis: automatic-failover-enabled="true")... CREATING
$ convox services
NAME                    TYPE      STATUS
redis-4799              redis     failed
```
. ElastiCache has the same concept of "MultiAZ" even though it's not a literal CF parameter.

It's tempting to have a --multi-az option that properly configures the CF stack with AutomaticFailoverEnabled and a minimum node type of cache.m3.medium.
. For redis i'm leaning very strongly towards the single --multi-az since its a first-class citizen across all datastores.
If MultiAZ=false, then the default InstanceType=cache.t2.micro and NumCacheClusters=1
If MultiAZ=true, then the default InstanceType=cache.m3.medium and NumCacheClusters=2.
I'm a bit split on the best way to implement this. 
The CLI or Controller could directly validate or select defaults for the set of MultiAZ, InstanceType and NumCacheClusters but then we move away from letting CloudFormation do everything.
The CF template could have some relatively straightforward Conditionals around the MultiAZ parameter. My main question here is how to handle defaults for NumCacheClusters and InstanceType. 
"NumCacheClusters": {
        "Type": "Number",
        "Default": "2",
        "Description": "If MultiAZ, the number of cache clusters for this replication group. Minimum 2, maximum 5."
      },
"InstanceType": {
        "Type": "String",
        "Default": "cache.t2.micro",
        "Description": "The type of instance to use."
      },
makes sense as the main default.
- Should the stack auto-magically pick cache.m3.medium if MultiAZ=true? 
- Or use the instance type and fail unless you explicitly set cache.m3.medium?
- Or have a MultiAZInstanceType that defaults to cache.m3.medium?
Not the most important decision either way. Documenting some options.

. I could use someone to double check all these ELB parameters... 
Default TCP
```
WebPort80Certificate=
WebPort80Protocol= (default TCP)
WebPort80ProxyProtocol= (default No)
ELB TCP -> Instance TCP
```
Turn on TCP proxy protocol to get CLIENT_IP
```
WebPort80Certificate=
WebPort80Protocol= (default TCP)
WebPort80ProxyProtocol=Yes
ELB TCP -> Instance TCP + ProxyProtocol
```
Change to HTTP to get X-Forwarded-For header
```
WebPort80Certificate=
WebPort80Protocol=HTTP
WebPort80ProxyProtocol= (default No)
ELB HTTP -> Instance HTTP
```
What happens if you do HTTP + Proxy Protocol?
```
WebPort80Certificate=
WebPort80Protocol=HTTP
WebPort80ProxyProtocol=Yes
ELB HTTP -> Instance HTTP + Proxy Protocol
```
Add a certificate. Default SSL -> TCP
```
WebPort80Certificate=ARN
WebPort80Protocol= (default TCP)
WebPort80ProxyProtocol= (default No)
WebPort80Secure= (default No)
ELB SSL -> Instance TCP
```
Turn on TCP proxy protocol to get CLIENT_IP
```
WebPort80Certificate=ARN
WebPort80Protocol= (default TCP)
WebPort80ProxyProtocol=Yes
WebPort80Secure= (default No)
ELB SSL -> Instance TCP + ProxyProtocol
```
If your process web server has a cert and talks HTTPS:
```
WebPort80Certificate=ARN
WebPort80Protocol= (default TCP)
WebPort80ProxyProtocol= (default No)
WebPort80Secure=Yes
ELB SSL -> Instance SSL
```
Turn on TCP proxy protocol to get CLIENT_IP
```
WebPort80Certificate=ARN
WebPort80Protocol= (default TCP)
WebPort80ProxyProtocol=Yes
WebPort80Secure=Yes
ELB SSL -> Instance SSL + ProxyProtocol
```

docker-compose.yml

Dockerfile
FROM nginx
COPY nginx.conf /etc/nginx/nginx.conf
nginx.conf
```
user  nginx;
worker_processes  1;
error_log  /var/log/nginx/error.log warn;
pid        /var/run/nginx.pid;
events {
    worker_connections  1024;
}
http {
    include       /etc/nginx/mime.types;
    default_type  application/octet-stream;
log_format combined '$proxy_protocol_addr - $remote_user [$time_local] '
                    '"$request" $status $body_bytes_sent '
                    '"$http_referer" "$http_user_agent"';

access_log  /var/log/nginx/access.log  main;

sendfile        on;
#tcp_nopush     on;

keepalive_timeout  65;

#gzip  on;

server {
    listen       80 proxy_protocol;
    server_name  localhost;

    location / {
        root   /usr/share/nginx/html;
        index  index.html index.htm;
    }

    #error_page  404              /404.html;

    # redirect server error pages to the static page /50x.html
    #
    error_page   500 502 503 504  /50x.html;
    location = /50x.html {
        root   /usr/share/nginx/html;
    }
}

}
```

. @mwarkentin I can't point you to a great reference off the top of my head, but in Go its ok and almost encouraged to do a little copy paste and to repeat yourself to have straightforward and self-contained functions. 
The idea is that its easier for a maintainer to come around and load the entire ManifestEntry.Label concept in her head and make safe modifications when its very procedural like this.
Certainly factoring out helpers into functions doesn't hurt, but its very different from ruby where metaprogramming can make really short functions with the actual intent and logic tucked away somewhere else.

. ## Amazon Linux 2016.03
On April 5th, Amazon sent this announcement:

We recently released a new Amazon ECS-optimized AMI that includes Amazon Linux 2016.03 and addresses an issue that causes the agent to stop accepting incoming requests.

This update starts using the amzn-ami-2016.03.a-amazon-ecs-optimized AMIs that are listed on the Launching an Amazon ECS Container Instance docs
Generally Convox is fast to follow AMI updates. However the upgrade from Amazon Linux 2015.09 to 2016.03 had system changes that caused some problems with the Convox UserData around restarting the Docker daemon to pick up custom settings. We now configure the instance with CloudInit which offers the ability to write custom Docker settings to the disk earlier in the boot process so they are there when the AMI does the first Docker start.
This is all for your information only. This is precisely the type of work we think Convox should sort out so you don't have to.
Thanks a ton to @bobzoller for contributing the original patch and @mwarkentin  for lots of testing.
SwapSize Parameter
Swap is now offered on a dedicated 5GB EBS volume. Advanced users can tune the amount of swap with the SwapSize Parameter.
Prior to this swap was a file on the root partition. In some cases this contributed to instance failures when the root partition is 100% full.
Most applications should not use swap, but we have seen some large Rails and Python apps benefit greatly from having swap available. To enable swap for an application, run convox env set SWAP=1. 
Note that ECS does not not yet support swap (GitHub issue) but Convox does!
InstanceRunCommand Parameter
Convox offers an experimental parameter, InstanceRunCommand, that enables you to customize your cluster without burning custom AMIs. 
You can use this to install custom packages on every instance:
$ convox rack params set InstanceRunCommand="yum install -y htop"
Run a Docker container on every instance:
$ convox rack params set InstanceRunCommand="docker run -d --rm logstash logstash -e 'input { stdin { } } output { stdout { } }'"
This can be extended to even setup complex monitoring tools like DataDog on every instance:
$ convox rack params set InstanceBootCommand="\"echo '**** START BOOTSTRAP ***' ; curl -H 'Authorization: token <token>' -H 'Accept: application/vnd.github.v3.raw' -o /tmp/bootstrap.sh -L https://raw.githubusercontent.com/user/repo/master/amazon-linux-ecs-bootstrap.sh ; DATADOG_API_KEY=<key> bash /tmp/bootstrap.sh\""
You do need to be careful about string and shell encoding on with this parameter.
Thanks to @mwarkentin for motivation and testing.
. If we wrap it in double quotes it mandates that you have to escape double quotes when setting it.
. @ddollar there should and will be a tool that helps set the right parameter for supported use cases like integrating DataDog and NewRelic server.

. @mwarkentin Currently there is no CloudFormation logic to not create the volume and initialize swap if set to 0.
If you set the param to 0 you get a rollback:
1 validation error detected: Value '0' at 'blockDeviceMappings.1.member.ebs.volumeSize' failed to satisfy constraint: Member must have value greater than or equal to 1
So the answer to your question is no, there is not a way to eliminate the swap partition right now. You can reduce it to 1GB to minimize the cost.
. Adding quoting now would technically be a backwards incompatible change as previous UserData implementation also had no quoting.
This is a fine design.
You get to control one line of cloud-init yaml. CloudInit supports unquoted, "quoted" and [argv, style] inputs which are all desirable for various use cases. Removing these options doesn't add any safety, even if we quoted around the input in the template you could still set a cloudformation parameter that doesn't have the proper inner quote escaping. If you get anything wrong it ultimately triggers a safe rollback

. @jordansexton really great feedback about staging environments, thanks.
There will always be a strong bias in Convox towards production environments. The goal is to deliver best practices out of the box: no single point of failure, multi-az placement, zero downtime deploys and fully automated deploys.
There should also be decreasingly less reasons to not follow the best practices in staging. 
What is your staging app footprint and price point? Would 2 t2.nanos make sense? They will cost < $9 / mo. on demand.
Turning off a staging or dev rack is a good technique. Another way to do this is to set up Scheduled Scaling. Manual modifications to the ASG will be honored independently of the rack InstanceCount parameter.
. The new default does not automatically change your rack. You will get an error when you try to update:

$ convox rack update
ERROR: ValidationError: Parameter 'InstanceCount' must be a number not less than 2
  status code: 400, request id: eefc5574-2cf6-11e6-abf1-0179c4f546cf

As for allowing 1 instance with a big warning, I'm still concerned about other side effects. 
One side effect I see is that we schedule 2 rack API containers for high availability of the control plane. Without conditionally scaling this down to 1 also, ECS will constantly be churning, and never detect and send notifications when any deployment is complete.
https://github.com/convox/rack/blob/master/api/dist/kernel.json#L1305
So I'd like to keep the default at 2 until someone presents a more comprehensive patch that addresses control plane, deployment and notifications challenges with 1 instance.

My understanding that because I already have pre-existing convox racks, I do not need to run that command at all.

That is correct. If you have one rack installed and running, you can develop "against" that. The docs try to address that here:


You can also use any existing Rack with the caveat that running a local Rack against it could have side effects like terminating instances.

instead of a git clone pulling the package with go

That's right. Rack is a Go project, so a working GOPATH and using the go tool is the best way to work with the project.

running ... is necessary for the local Rack environment to know about AWS secrets

That's right, and this snippet is surely some wizardry.
On AWS the rack web process is running with a bunch of AWS secrets and resource names in its environment. You can introspect any running process with the convox exec command and its process id, so this snippet figures out the process id and runs env.
Then you can save this environment to your laptop and start a web binary in development and to make rapid changes locally.
Finally you tell the convox CLI to talk to your local web server.

"Rack" refers to the project name whereas a rack

Naming is hard! I say the project name is convox/rack, following GitHub and Go conventions. 
"Rack" is also a code name we use to refer to your AWS VPC, instances and other related resources. Sometimes I refer to this same concept as your "VPC" or "Cluster".
I hope that helps a bit. Any feedback on how the Developing.md can be more clear is appreciated.

. The way to develop new services locally is:
- Go through the Development Guide to convox start a local Rack API and convox login localhost to get the CLI to talk to it
- Fork one of the files in api/models/templates/service, i.e. cp redis.tmpl memcache.tmpl
Then you can iterate around:
- Change parts of the CloudFormation template to provision your new service.
- Run make templates to compile your template and reload the development rack API
- Run convox services create memcache
- Use the CloudFormation Management Console and events to see errors in creating the service

. ## Rack Instance Count Validation
A rack requires at least 2 instances for:
- Running the rack API in a redundant fashion
- Spare capacity for a rolling deploy of a web process
- Service uptime or fast recovery when an instance dies.
So if you try running a rack with a single instance, strange side effects happen. Therefore we now prevent the ability to install or scale down a rack to a single instance. 
Thanks to @markpundsack for a bug report, and @kmonkeyjam for a bug report and a patch!
Uninstall Robustness
Based on lots of feedback @nzoschke made convox uninstall much more robust. It now:
- Requires an explicit rack name and region preventing accidental rack deletion
- Deletes all services and apps automatically
- Retries deleting every service, app and rack to work around transient errors
- Empties and deletes S3 buckets
We hope that this makes Convox even easier to experiment with.
Dev Environment Supports More Project Types
@mattmanning is working hard on improving the convox development environment.
In this release, convox start has more smarts for projects with no Dockerfile / docker-compose.yml, and projects with a Procfile. Use convox update to update the CLI for these enhancements.

. ## Rack CPU Utilization
convox instances was incorrectly calculating 0% CPU Utilization based off the ECS Instances CPU reservation information. We now pull the proper CPU Utilization Average value directly from CloudWatch Metrics:
bash

i-ff44b863  on     active  5 days ago  2   1.66%  6.41%
i-d1ec644b  on     active  3 days ago  0   0.29%  0.00%
The result of expertly wrapping these low level AWS services is a Convox REST API that is really easy to work with for monitoring and automation:

EC2 Container Registry In Ireland (eu-west-1)
AWS released its highly scalable, high performance Docker image registry service in Ireland a few weeks ago. Convox users in eu-west-1 will start using it after the next convox rack update and two app deploys.
We expect this to be faster and more reliable than the legacy private registry running in your rack. One more region to go (Tokyo ap-northeast-1) before we can remove the legacy private registry for good!
Scale Down to Delete Unneeded ELBs
If you scale a web process down to 0, convox retains the ELB so you will keep the same hostname if and when you scale a web process back up to 1 or more.
This has an unfortunate side effect of costing some of us $18/mo for an ELB we may not be using. Now you can scale a web process down to -1 to de-provision the ELB and save money:
```
$ convox scale web --count=-1
NAME  DESIRED  RUNNING  MEMORY
web   -1       0        256 
$ convox apps info
Name       httpd
Status     running
Release    RDJQJEUAPTP
Processes  web
Endpoints  :80 (web)
```
At any time you can scale back up to 0 or more to create a new ELB. The hostname will be different but your service will be back online in minutes.

It is possible to specify a custom keypair and use that to SSH directly into the box. But in practice nobody is (or should be doing this) over convox ssh. Perhaps there should be docs somewhere that document this...
Anyway +1 on the patch. Going to test/release it on #725

. Rails looks like this when you scale the database to -1:

. Verified this is working with a branch release. More testing and release on #725
. Syslog bugfixes and papertrail deprecation has been released. Had success with our customers in migrating from papertrail to syslog. Going to start testing this PR more seriously.
. Testing update when papertrial is installed:
```
$ convox services create papertrail --url logs4.papertrailapp.com:111111
Creating papertrail-7102 (papertrail: url="logs4.papertrailapp.com:111111")... CREATING
$ convox services link papertrail-7102 --app httpd-old
Linked papertrail-7102 to httpd-old
link to an app that has kinesis removed
$ convox services link papertrail-7102 --app httpd
ERROR: response status: 500
```
. Updating a rack that removes kinesis when it has a papertrail link cleanly disables the event source in Lambda:

Similarly deploying an app that removes kinesis disables the event source.
. Deleting papertrail service with existing links, disabled or not, works fine.
. convox/agent doesn't try to write to kinesis if a container doesn't have the KINESIS env var set. So its all good for apps / racks with removed kinesis.
. CI is failing more than I'd like with this release. I just tracked down the probable reason why:
$ convox run --app httpd-807 web echo "hello world"
hello world
ERROR: API error (404): rpc error: code = 2 desc = "containerd: container not found"
. ## VPC Security Enhancements
The Rack VPC Security Group no longer exposes the SSH port to the world (0.0.0.0/0). It now accepts traffic only from inside the Rack VPC, which is sufficient because of the convox instances ssh websocket tunneling.
Thanks @beedub for the security improvement!
Docker Daemon Changes
This week we discovered that Docker 1.11 was surprisingly showing up in production environments, and causing convox run to errantly exit non-zero in some cases. 
The new update no longer applies updates on boot for anything but critical system security, effctively pinning Docker back to 1.09.
We will update Docker to 1.11 along with new ECS AMIs in the near future.
This update also changes the Docker Daemon limit for number of open files from 1024 to 1024000. @awsmsrc found a great suggestion for a higher limit by @pahud on Medium as a much better setting for modern web applications.
Papertrail Deprecation
In anticipation of removing Kinesis to save us all money this update blocks convox service create papertrail.
Now you should use convox services create syslog --url tcp+tls://logs1.papertrailapp.com:12345 to forward logs from CloudWatch Logs to Papertrail via secure syslog. See the Syslog Docs for more information.
Scale Down to Delete Unneded ELBs
@mwarkentin reported a couple bugs in the new feature that removes unneeded ELBs. You can now run convox scale redis --count=-1 to remove ELBs, even if they are linked to another process. You can also still convox run redis bash even if the process type is not running.

. Looks good to me. 20 does seem over-provisioned in hind sight
. This looks good. ECS and Autoscaling are decoupled so I don't see one blocking the other.
With the convox configuration, we'll boot 5 new servers and wait for them to be fully initialized and signal back to cloudformation, then terminate 5 old ones.
The risk is that all the containers on the 5 old instances will be terminated at roughly the same time. If those 5 instances contain many or all of the web containers for a service, you could have total downtime. This will be temporary as they'll be re-scheduled and boot back up across the cluster in short order.
So the InstanceUpdateBatchSize of 1 has a subtle side effect that we'll never take down more than 1 web process per app at a time every.
With a setting like InstanceUpdateBatchSize=5, are your critical services scaled up so that losing 5 web containers at a time would be ok?
. Nice!
I have some high level questions, as I've intentionally ignored what CPU shares can accomplish on ECS up until now for simplicity sake.
Can you offer some use cases for setting CPU shares differently among apps and process types?
How does settings CPU shares affect the runtime for processes? Do they get throttled or killed if they use too much?

. Awesome research. Let me try to synthesize what you've found...
CPU shares are an important concept for apps, particularly for controlling how many cores a container can access / saturate.
On ECS, CPU shares are a hard limit for scheduling.
I don't quite get the Docker CPU shares stuff... My initial reaction is that it doesn't matter, just work with ECS.


I do think having this setting, and setting it to a sane default is important though. Without a cpu setting at all, one could launch a process accidentally that saturates cpu and adversely affect every other app and process running in the rack.

I think the default is the main design decision here.
My Convox philosophy is sane defaults, then some simple knobs, but let power users do whatever they want with these knobs including shooting yourself in the foot.
I definitely understand your concern about a process gone wild.
But I think that saturating a CPU is actually a feature in a single-tenant system. Squeeze everything you can out of the boxes, and only tune things if you observe quality of service problems.
The main justification I see for this default is the ECS API and system itself. For every Task Definition, Memory is required and CPU is not.
The next justification is backwards compatibility. If we're not careful the next app deploy for all users will magically have some tight CPU limits. If the default is wrong, we should change it, but probably with a more careful migration strategy.
So what if the default was still 0, but your parameterization lands so you and everyone else can start playing with tuning it?

. ## Critical Fix For Scaling API
There have been 2 reports of inadvertently deleting an ELB when doing a convox scale --memory=X operation on a recent release. 
We recommend everyone convox update your CLI immediately, and convox rack update at your nearest convenience to avoid this problem.
With an older CLI (< 20160529014122) and a newer Rack (>= 20160602143119) doing a convox scale --memory=512 on older clients sends a count=-1 value as a default, triggering the new convox scale --count=-1 feature to intentionally scale down a process and remove its ELB.
This release adds a CLI version check to avoid the side effect.

. > Is the design appropriate?
The labels to parameters pattern is working out well, so yes I think this is a good design in general.
+1 to David's suggestion of shortening / combining these as much as possible. 
The things I see to tune are:
- Timeout
- Turn it into a path-based HTTP check
- Explicitly pick a port if I've mapped many
So I propose 3 labels: port, path, and timeout.
We already know what container ports should be alive from the port mapping and what protocols the container ports talks from the convox.port.443.protocol=tcp|http and convox.port.443.secure=true labels.
We can always pick a naive default of TCP to any port that is exposed.
Here are some other use cases I see...
My app takes a long time to boot so I add a single new label:
yaml
web:
  labels:
    - convox.health.timeout=120
  ports:
    - 80:5000
My service exposes a "deep" health check endpoint over HTTP so I add a single new label:
yaml
web:
  labels:
    - convox.health.path=/foo
  ports:
    - 80:5000
I'm a total power user and want to assert health on my end-to-end encrypted service (not on the redirect port):
yaml
web:
  labels:
    - convox.port.443.protocol=https
    - convox.port.443.secure=true
    - convox.health.path=/foo
    - convox.health.port=5001
    - convox.health.timeout=120
  ports:
    - 80:5000
    - 443:5001
. > I'm still a bit unclear about the rules for setting defaults in the cloudformation template according to convox. When does it make sense to specify a default?
Most parameters need default values. The exceptions are:
- Convox might supply its own values on every stack update (i.e. rack/app Version parameter)
- The Parameter has a related Conditional that might toggle something off if the value is empty (i.e. Ami parameter and BlankAmi conditional)
. > I have an inkling to add or update integration tests but could use some guidance here
Adding some more YAML -> CF fixtures would be appropriate here. Add something like custom-health.yml that has the new labels to rack/api/models/fixtures, then type make fixtures. It should generate the cloudformation .json.
This will require manual verification but once the .json is considered correct but all of us it will help with regression testing and patches going forward.

. @beedub a few reasons I have against parameterizing health_threshold, unhealthy_threshold and interval...

Good "developer experience" comes from removing complexity and optionality. From my experience, boot timeout is the concept everyone cares about and understands for their app, interval and threshold is implementation details.
There is a hard limit of max 60 parameters on every CF stack, and folks that have a bunch of process types are already hitting this. Adding a lot of new parameters could push more apps over the edge.
There's always a super dangerous power mode where you can tweak any settings not parameterized on AWS directly. While I don't recommend this in general, it's a great way for us to experiment before making a label / knob something we add to the platform.
. I think its:
- TCP to the first port by default
- HTTP to the first port if there is a .path label
- HTTPS if there is a .path label and the first port or specified port also has a secure=true label
So the convox.port.443.secure and convox.health.port=443 labels are coupled.
I do have a sense that this is pretty "clever", but I think this stuff is pretty tricky in general and we can have validation and feedback on convox start and good tests about yaml -> parameters.

The list 250 and delete anything over 200 is a clever strategy to get around APIs or calls to get the length of the collection and delete things in reverse.
One other big gotcha I see is that a build can produce many images (web, worker, redis and postgres). So 200 builds could be more than 500 images and trigger the limits. A couple solutions I see to this is to pick an even smaller max number of builds, or to introspect ECR to see how many images it has and use that as criteria to delete the oldest builds.
. In my anecdotal experience users care about:
- The last build in case of emergency rollback
- The last couple weeks of builds at most behind that
So I think 100 would be more than enough.

. ## Process CPU Configuration
Thanks to @beedub you can now configure CPU shares for any process type.
The default is still the same -- not explicitly changing this setting means that all processes share all of the CPU available on an instance. This is still the sensible default to get the most out of CPUs in the cluster.
But the ability to specify this opens up some more powerful use cases.
If you set a worker CPU shares to a small number with convox apps params set WorkerCpu=50 it will restrict the amount of CPU -- most importantly the number of CPU cores -- that a single worker can consume. For some apps this is a very good way to assure that the web processes don't get adversely impacted by workers.
See #741 for lots of good discussion about the use cases and implementation.
Custom App Load Balancers Security Groups
Convox handles provisioning and configuring a load balancer based on the docker-compose.yml port mappings:
yaml
web:
  image: httpd
  ports: 80:80
By default this load balancer will be exposed to the entire internet. Sometimes we want to tighten this to only allow connections from a single computer or single network.
You can now apply additional restrictions to this load balancer by assigning a custom security group to an app:
``` bash
get the VPC ID
$ convox rack
Name     convox
Status   running
Version  20160615203231
Region   us-east-1
Count    3
Type     t2.large
$ convox ps --app convox
ID            NAME      RELEASE                  SIZE  STARTED     COMMAND                         
cde9ac958f36  monitor   20160615203231-20160615  64    4 days ago  /go/bin/init sh -c api/bin/monitor
1845eb6ec788  registry  20160615203231-20160615  128   1 day ago   /docker-entrypoint.sh           
79e05a82d06d  registry  20160615203231-20160615  128   4 days ago  /docker-entrypoint.sh           
541d9b8509cb  web       20160615203231-20160615  128   1 day ago   /go/bin/init sh -c api/bin/web  
e9fd0ed66d41  web       20160615203231-20160615  128   4 days ago  /go/bin/init sh -c api/bin/web 
$ convox exec 541d9b8509cb env --app convox | grep VPC
VPC=vpc-f8006b9c
create a new security group
$ aws ec2 create-security-group --group-name=office --description="office network only" --vpc-id=vpc-f8006b9c
{
    "GroupId": "sg-3bdaaf40"
}
restrict ingress to a single subnet
$ aws ec2 authorize-security-group-ingress --group-id=sg-3bdaaf40 --protocol=tcp --port=0-65535 --cidr=24.75.239.0/32
apply the security group to the app load balancers
$ convox apps params set SecurityGroup=sg-3bdaaf40
Updating parameters... OK
```
After this, the service will only be accessable to IPs from the specified subnet, blocking access from the internet at large.
See @MiguelMoll's patch on #775 for more information.
Build Cleanup
AWS ECR has a default limit of 500 Docker Images, which you can eventually hit after many builds. Thanks to @awsmsrc on #773, convox now automatically deletes the very oldest builds after a successful new build. This both avoids hitting the service limit and saves money on storage costs.
As a reminder, Convox still retains the last 50 builds and releases to facilitate a rollback from a bad release:
``` bash
$ convox builds
ID           STATUS    RELEASE      STARTED      ELAPSED  DESC
BOFEDWPIEEB  complete  RLBTJENIMQI  3 days ago   6s         
BVFZQPTJJNV  complete  RTAYZHUSGCJ  1 week ago   22s        
BKYKUURZKQU  complete  RONCLAIMWTP  2 weeks ago  49s        
BFUOFQOMAFI  complete  RDJQJEUAPTP  2 weeks ago  10s        
BHGAKQOJCCA  complete  RQOHWZJYDGG  2 weeks ago  5s       
$ convox releases promote RTAYZHUSGCJ
Promoting RTAYZHUSGCJ... UPDATING
```

. I assumed that the cli library should be like:
convox                      -> app template
convox help              -> app template
convox ps                 -> command template
convox ps help         -> command template
convox ps stop         -> subcommand template
convox ps stop help -> subcommand template
surprised to learn that there it isn't like this. I like the direction of this. I can see a comprehensive CLI output testing drive:

Better user experience
Consistency / polish of the CLI
Safer and faster changes to CLI commands
Safer and faster changes to CLI stdout/stderr formatting

The various help commands is a nice way to establish coverage since its very user-centric (getting missing, bad or confusing help is not helpful) and doesn't require any test server stuff.

LGTM, but it's tricky so let me make sure I understand...
The minimum value of CPU shares according to Linux is "2", and the max is "1024".
A value of "2" means that a container is guaranteed only 2 CPU shares, but can burst up to 1024 shares as long as it doesn't step on other container guarantees. This means that all the containers with a value of "2" should be very "nice" and not hog CPU resources.
A value of "1024" means that the container is effectively given an entire CPU core. Though Linux still has some rules about two containers with "1024" sharing a single core fairly.
The value of "2" is a reasonable default for every container, unless a user explicitly wants to enable a container to guarantee more CPU resources if there is contention.
On one ECS agent, a TD value of "null" or "0" used to be converted to "1024", and a value of "1" used to be converted to "2".
On the latest ECS agent, "null", "0", "1" and "2" are converted to "2".
This logic defaults "null", "0", "1" and "2" explicitly to "2" to provide the reasonable default for any version of the ECS agent.
. LGTM, but it's tricky so let me make sure I understand...
The minimum value of CPU shares according to Linux is "2", and the max is "1024".
A value of "2" means that a container is guaranteed only 2 CPU shares, but can burst up to 1024 shares as long as it doesn't step on other container guarantees. This means that all the containers with a value of "2" should be very "nice" and not hog CPU resources.
A value of "1024" means that the container is effectively given an entire CPU core. Though Linux still has some rules about two containers with "1024" sharing a single core fairly.
The value of "2" is a reasonable default for every container, unless a user explicitly wants to enable a container to guarantee more CPU resources if there is contention.
On one ECS agent, a TD value of "null" or "0" used to be converted to "1024", and a value of "1" used to be converted to "2".
On the latest ECS agent, "null", "0", "1" and "2" are converted to "2".
This logic defaults "null", "0", "1" and "2" explicitly to "2" to provide the reasonable default for any version of the ECS agent.

```patch
diff --git a/bin/test b/bin/test

+go get -ldflags=-s -t ./...

@@ -12,16 +12,16 @@ export CLI_TEMPLATE_ERROR_DEBUG=true
 if [ ! -z ${PKG} ]; then
     if [ ! -z ${TEST} ]; then
         echo "Running single test $TEST"
-        go test -coverprofile=profile.out -covermode=atomic "$PKG" -test.run "$TEST"

         exit
     fi

go test -coverprofile=profile.out -covermode=atomic "$PKG"
go test -ldflags=-s -coverprofile=profile.out -covermode=atomic "$PKG"
     exit
 fi

for d in $(find . -not ( -name vendor -prune ) -name '*.go' -exec dirname {} \; | sort -u); do
-  go test -coverprofile=profile.out -covermode=atomic $d
+  go test -ldflags=-s -coverprofile=profile.out -covermode=atomic $d
if [ -f profile.out ]; then
     cat profile.out >> coverage.txt

. @nzoschke 
I will use the terms "unbound" and "bound" to refer to apps and services created before and after this patch, respectively. An unbound app/service does not have a rack prefix.
It's not be possible to create unbound apps or services. All new stacks will be prefixed. However, if an unbound app or service already exists, creation will fail to prevent logical duplicates.
Calls to GetApp(name) and GetService(name) attempt to locate a stack called name before trying rack-name. That is, older, unbound names are preferred to preserve backwards compatibility. If name matches the current rack name, only name will be attempted.
Bound apps and services have an additional Name tag used by the App.StackName() and Service.StackName() methods to determine the fully qualified name. This is the only detectable difference between bound and unbound stacks. As such, using one of these methods is the preferred and safest way to derive the correct stack name.
Per the last section, app = &models.App{Name: name} is no longer a safe way to interact with App or Service models, you should instead use GetApp or GetService. Tag information is necessary to determine the real .StackName().
Docker repositories use .StackName() to avoid clashing with similar apps on a different rack.
Everything needing account-wide uniqueness should also use .StackName().

. Can we make the delimiters something not possible to be in a stack name?
These rack-app-procs would hash the same (because part of the app name in one is now part of the proc name in the second, but they are the same hash input) and truncate too early to fix the hash collision:
```
rack, aaaaaaaaaaaaaaapp, hai-process
rack-aaaaaaaaaaaaaapp-B32HASH(rack-aaaaaaaaaaaaaaapp-hai-process)
rack, aaaaaaaaaaaaaapp-hai, process
rack-aaaaaaaaaaaaaapp-B32HASH(rack-aaaaaaaaaaaaaaapp-hai-process)
```
Using a delimiter that cannot be in a stack name results in this:
```
rack, aaaaaaaaaaaaaaapp, hai-process
rack-aaaaaaaaaaaaaapp-B32HASH(rack:aaaaaaaaaaaaaaapp:hai-process)
rack, aaaaaaaaaaaaaapp-hai, process
rack-aaaaaaaaaaaaaapp-B32HASH(rack:aaaaaaaaaaaaaaapp-hai:process)
```
I know it's a little contrived, but it's a possible collision and easy to fix right now.

There is a small race here on stack delete and emptying the bucket... if it takes a brillion years for cleanupBucket to empty the target bucket, and the stack is dropped really fast, there is a chance the bucket delete will fail with some nonempty error... but that just brings us back to where we are now :-)
. Is there a reason apps spawn their own S3 buckets instead of using a prefix within a shared rack bucket? The default bucket limit is only 100 and before this patch we bumped that pretty quick just from development churn (add/deleting apps).
. How long does it take for the other goroutines to clean the bucket? In practice so far it's been trying to drop the bucket long after emptying it, succeeding... I think. I only tried with apps deployed once. I'll look closer tomorrow.
Maybe apps with many more objects/logs would take too long?
What is the right thing?
. App.Delete calls cleanupBucket via go a.Cleanup() after a successful DeleteStack call. Since the stack takes time to delete, the goroutines dropping S3 objects seem to have enough time to drain everything before all the other resources in the stack are cleaned up by CF. Cleanup waits for the stack drop (up to 10 minutes) and if it happens, the bucket is dropped then too.

Did some debugging on a hangout w/ @nzoschke - turns out our InstanceBootCommand had multiple :s (setting headers in a curl command) - these were inside the yaml for cloud-init, which parsed them as yaml dictionaries. The fix was to wrap the entire boot command in quotes like so: convox rack params set InstanceBootCommand="\"echo '**** START WAVE BOOTSTRAP ***' ; curl -H 'Authorization: token ...' -H 'Accept: application/vnd.github.v3.raw' ... bash /tmp/bootstrap.sh\""
This should be documented.
The other alternative would be for convox to automatically wrap the InstanceBootParam in quotes before injecting into the cloud-init yaml, but this could potentially have some side effects?

. Yeah, I don't really think that this is a workable solution for us - many of our apps have both web processes (need to be reachable from host) as well as rpc processes for inter-app communication (communicating between docker containers should work great).
With that said, I don't have any specific suggestions at this point - the best I've got right now is being able to specify a unique local port for dev (which gives us multi-app access from the host, fixes port conflicts) and specify a different port to be exposed on the ELB (which we want to be 443 for all of our apps so we can access over HTTPS without specifying a port in our dev/stage/production racks).
Perhaps that looks something like this in docker-compose.yml:
yaml
web:
  build: .
  command: actions/web.sh
  environment:
    - DEVELOPMENT_MODE=true
    - WEB_CONCURRENCY=2
  labels:
    - convox.elb.port=443  # Replace 9001 with 443 on the ELB
    - convox.port.443.protocol=https
  ports:
    - 9001:80  # Unique port for local dev
  links:
    - redis
redis:
  image: convox/redis
  ports:
    - 9301
Looking at this some more, this actually looks like it could be a good solution for our apps rpc communication for local dev (which we haven't needed yet in the first two apps). Need to think on that some more - might not be an issue because we could use unique ports for those already (and I think communicate over the docker network with those ports), since we don't have the 443 requirement that we have for web traffic..

. I think some sort of increased amount of time is important - this has been causing us all sorts of problems with any sort of rack update that requires a new set of instances (rack version updates, AMI changes, changing instance type). It seems (though I don't have hard numbers) that these updates would fail 40-50% of the time after hitting the 15m timeout because 3-4 instances in a row were started and then marked as unhealthy by the convox/monitor process due to the ECS agent being disconnected. Sometimes the rollback would fail for the same reason, and we would have to manually trigger a re-rollback.
Our workaround for now is going to be disabling the convox/monitor ECS service before running any sort of rack update, but that's pretty hacky.

jordansexton:
I updated to the latest and I'm still running into #449. Is this released yet? I'm probably just confused about how releases are done.
. @nzoschke Do you happen to have any update on the CLI release for this? I'm able to test the rack update but not locally. Is there a way I'm missing to install a specific CLI version, or only installing from source?
. > there should be at least 1 more instance than the number of processes your app is scaled to
Can anyone explain why this is? Requiring 2 instances for a tiny app seems heavy handed, and I haven't had any issues with needing to stop tasks when deploying.
Edit: This is especially true for staging environments where zero downtime updates are not important. Wouldn't it be possible to simply warn on < 2 instances rather than error?
. This is also a problem:
convox rack scale --count 0
ERROR: count must be greater than 1
There's no way to just scale a rack off now (also useful for staging environments). In short, this minimum of 2 only applies to production deployments.
. The params of the CFT are also validated, preventing it from being scaled down without the CLI.

. @nzoschke Thanks for the detailed response, and that's a good point about scheduled scaling. It's something that could probably work for us if we tweak our workflow a bit.
However, would it be a problem to allow overriding the minimum if desired? I definitely understand the focus on production environments, but why not default to >= 2 instances, but still allow < 2 and just insert a descriptive (and perhaps scary) warning?
I suppose the default of 2 means that existing deployments (like our staging env) go up to 2 instances when upgraded, but it would be nice to be able to just scale the rack down to 1 or 0 rather than rely on scheduling. So far we've been able to use convox directly without even worrying about the AWS CLI or thinking about CFTs lately and it's been pretty great 😀
Anyway, I admit my reaction was in part due to surprise about the change, so please feel free to close this issue if the current behavior seems like the balance you want to strike.

. ## DynamoDB Indexes Enhancements
For a majority of users, the decreased provisioned throughput for build and release DynamoDB tables will result in a monthly savings!
Thanks @frsechet for the improvement!
For more info see PR #736: changed provisioned throughput for DynamoDB indexes.
Git Submodules Checkout
This enhancement allows convox build to pull/update a repo's submodules, if any.
Thanks @mfine for the improvement!
For more information see PR #732: Update submodules on git checkout
Autoscaling Improvements
PR #737 made some improvements for scaling a rack. With the rack Autoscale parameter enabled,
there is no need to use the --count option to increase the instance count. A Rack can scale its own instance count based on the needs of the containers it provisions.
. These improvements have been published with version 20160607215357.

. ## Upgrade to docker 1.11
With Docker finally removing the -f option (thanks to @asyazwan for bringing it to our attention with #781), we decided the best route is to upgrade to Docker 1.11.
This includes the the alpine imaged used by rack itself but also an AMI optimize for ECS Instances:
```
The current Amazon ECS-optimized AMI (amzn-ami-2016.03.c-amazon-ecs-optimized) consists of:
The latest minimal version of the Amazon Linux AMI
The latest version of the Amazon ECS container agent (1.10.0)
The recommended version of Docker for the latest Amazon ECS container agent (1.11.1)
The latest version of the ecs-init package to run and monitor the Amazon ECS agent (1.10.0-1)
```
See PR #797 for more information.
Process CPU Configuration
Thanks to @beedub you can now configure CPU shares for any process type.
The default is still the same -- not explicitly changing this setting means that all processes share all of the CPU available on an instance. This is still the sensible default to get the most out of CPUs in the cluster.
But the ability to specify this opens up some more powerful use cases. You'd be able to set the number of CPU units to reserve for for a process. 
For example, if you run a single-container web process on a single-core instance type with 512 CPU units specified for that container, and that is the only task running on the container instance, that container could use the full 1,024 CPU unit share at any given time. However, if you launched another copy of the same web process on that container instance, each task would be guaranteed a minimum of 512 CPU units when needed, and each container could float to higher CPU usage if the other container was not using it, but if both tasks were 100% active all of the time, they would be limited to 512 CPU units.
More information is available in the AWS documentation.
See #741 for lots of good discussion about the use cases and implementation.
Custom App Load Balancers Security Groups
Convox handles provisioning and configuring a load balancer based on the docker-compose.yml port mappings:
yaml
web:
  image: httpd
  ports:
    - 80:80
By default this load balancer will be exposed to the entire internet. Sometimes we want to tighten this to only allow connections from a single computer or single network.
You can now apply additional restrictions to this load balancer by assigning a custom security group to an app:
``` bash
get the VPC ID
$ convox rack
Name     convox
Status   running
Version  20160615203231
Region   us-east-1
Count    3
Type     t2.large
$ convox ps --app convox
ID            NAME      RELEASE                  SIZE  STARTED     COMMAND                         
cde9ac958f36  monitor   20160615203231-20160615  64    4 days ago  /go/bin/init sh -c api/bin/monitor
1845eb6ec788  registry  20160615203231-20160615  128   1 day ago   /docker-entrypoint.sh           
79e05a82d06d  registry  20160615203231-20160615  128   4 days ago  /docker-entrypoint.sh           
541d9b8509cb  web       20160615203231-20160615  128   1 day ago   /go/bin/init sh -c api/bin/web  
e9fd0ed66d41  web       20160615203231-20160615  128   4 days ago  /go/bin/init sh -c api/bin/web 
$ convox exec 541d9b8509cb env --app convox | grep VPC
VPC=vpc-f8006b9c
create a new security group
$ aws ec2 create-security-group --group-name=office --description="office network only" --vpc-id=vpc-f8006b9c
{
    "GroupId": "sg-3bdaaf40"
}
restrict ingress to a single subnet
$ aws ec2 authorize-security-group-ingress --group-id=sg-3bdaaf40 --protocol=tcp --port=0-65535 --cidr=24.75.239.0/32
apply the security group to the app load balancers
$ convox apps params set SecurityGroup=sg-3bdaaf40
Updating parameters... OK
```
After this, the service will only be accessable to IPs from the specified subnet, blocking access from the internet at large.
See @MiguelMoll's patch on #775 for more information.
Build Cleanup
AWS ECR has a default limit of 500 Docker Images, which you can eventually hit after many builds. Thanks to @awsmsrc on #773, convox now automatically deletes the very oldest builds after a successful new build. This both avoids hitting the service limit and saves money on storage costs.
As a reminder, Convox still retains the last 50 builds and releases to facilitate a rollback from a bad release:
``` bash
$ convox builds
ID           STATUS    RELEASE      STARTED      ELAPSED  DESC
BOFEDWPIEEB  complete  RLBTJENIMQI  3 days ago   6s         
BVFZQPTJJNV  complete  RTAYZHUSGCJ  1 week ago   22s        
BKYKUURZKQU  complete  RONCLAIMWTP  2 weeks ago  49s        
BFUOFQOMAFI  complete  RDJQJEUAPTP  2 weeks ago  10s        
BHGAKQOJCCA  complete  RQOHWZJYDGG  2 weeks ago  5s       
$ convox releases promote RTAYZHUSGCJ
Promoting RTAYZHUSGCJ... UPDATING
```

. ## General Enhancements
- Use same hostname for linked containers (PR #836)
  - This enhancement allows for better consistency between convox start and docker-compose up.
- Tag Subnets with a "Name" (PR #828)
  - Allows for better organization and identification of subnets used throughout a rack.
- Get a service's URL (PR #825)
  -  With the various convox services supported, sometimes you need easy access to that service's endpoint. 
  - convox services url <service> makes that happen: 
```
  $ convox services
  NAME             TYPE    STATUS
  s3-111          s3      running
$ convox services url s3-1111
  s3://misc123:misc123@convox-rack-s3-111
  ```
Very script friendly!

. Sure. Since Rack runs two copies of the Rack API process for optimal uptime, if a Rack doesn't have at least three instances updates can't roll out and your CloudFormation stack will get wedged. 
When Cloudformation tries to rollback the update, the limit of two instances prevents the rollback from succeeding. We've seen a few users getting stuck because of this scenario recently.. . This can indeed take a while, especially if a user calls convox run with a very old release. The go-ecs API doesn't provide a "paging" functionality like it's other calls for describing task definitions (which is understandable since we want to describe one revision).
Two options top of mind:
1. Sleep for a second after n number of task definitions. (arbitrarily start with 15?).
2. Limit convox run to use only one of the last n task definitions. (again 15 might work).
These options help with rate limits. There's still the issue of a run taking too long. Especially if it's towards the bottom of the list. More recent releases would be towards the top of the list and are iterated over first.
I'm leaning towards option 2. As is, to determine if a release hasn't been promoted, we have to iterate the task definitions revisions. If it's not found there then it's an "unpromoted" release. It would be a bad user experience having to wait that iteration if there are hundreds of revisions to iterate first.

. > Can you offer some use cases for setting CPU shares differently among apps and process types?
In a single app, we have a worker tier for cpu-intensive processes like image processing and a worker tier for everything else. We'd want to guarantee, for example, than the the image processing workers had atleast 2 cores available to it (represented through 2048 cpu units in ecs). Similarly, we'd want the worker tier to have atleast 1 core (represented by 1024 cpu units). It's also easy to imagine different types of apps running in one rack as well. For us, we have a main application for which each container spawns 4 workers, and we have newer microservices that only have 2 workers each. For the former, we'd like to dedicate atleast 2 cores worth of units to it, and the former 1 core.

How does settings CPU shares affect the runtime for processes? Do they get throttled or killed if they use too much?

From what I've read and demos I've seen, they are simply throttled to that amount if there are competing processes on the box. They are not killed. https://goldmann.pl/blog/2014/09/11/resource-management-in-docker/

I believe the total number of CPU shares differs among instance type. Does the process type setting need to take this into account?

The vCPU shares are different per instance type. There's a coarse check for the cpu setting in the PR that's similar to the check for the memory setting: the validation will check that the rack instance type has atleast enough overall cpu shares to satisfy the cpu setting. However, similar to memory constraints, this won't guarantee that the process can be placed. Eg. if you had one t1.small (has 1 vCPU/1024 cpu units) with the convox agent running with 256 cpu units, and tried to launch a process with 1024, then it may (will? I'll verify after this comment) not get placed.
I do think having this setting, and setting it to a sane default is important though. Without a cpu setting at all, one could launch a process accidentally that saturates cpu and adversely affect every other app and process running in the rack. Now that I think about it, I think it might be more intuitive to set the default to 512 (half a cpu core minimum) or 1024 (one core minimum).
. I tested the cpu shares on an ECS cluster. ECS will deny placing the task if there exists no capacity on any instances that fits the CPU requirement.
. I did a little bit more testing and research on cpu...
There are two aspects to consider: ecs' cpu units and docker cpu shares. They are almost similar but not exactly the same. While ecs' cpu units are a hard limit and relative value, docker cpu shares are only a relative value. This means that the docker daemon on the instance can handle way instances 
ECS translates cpu to docker --cpu-shares according to the following chart:
| cpu units | available cpu change | --cpu-shares value |
| --- | --- | --- |
| not specified / null / 0 | 0 | 2 |
| 1 | -1 | 2 |
| N > 1 | -N | N |
Currently, convox doesn't specify a cpu for its task definitions, so available cpu units on all instances is the max allowed and each task/process is launched with a docker cpu share of 2. As an example, if the cluster has 1 t2.small with 1 vCPU (1024 cpu units) and 3 running tasks each with share 2, then each task will be guaranteed 2/1024 cpu units and each will equally share the remaining unreserved cpu units (1024 - 2 * 3).
. After re-considering, I agree that leaving the cpu default as null makes
more sense than setting it to something arbitrary. As long as it's
configurable, I'm :+1:
On Thu, Jun 9, 2016 at 5:44 PM, Noah Zoschke notifications@github.com
wrote:

Awesome research. Let me try to synthesize what you've found...
CPU shares are an important concept for apps, particularly for controlling
how many cores a container can access / saturate.
On ECS, CPU shares are a hard limit for scheduling.
I don't quite get the Docker CPU shares stuff... My initial reaction is
that it doesn't matter, just work with ECS.
I do think having this setting, and setting it to a sane default is
important though. Without a cpu setting at all, one could launch a process
accidentally that saturates cpu and adversely affect every other app and
process running in the rack.
I think the default is the main design decision here.
My Convox philosophy is sane defaults, then some simple knobs, but let
power users do whatever they want with these knobs including shooting
yourself in the foot.
I definitely understand your concern about a process gone wild.
But I think that saturating a CPU is actually a feature in a single-tenant
system. Squeeze everything you can out of the boxes, and only tune things
if you observe quality of service problems.
The main justification I see for this default is the ECS API and system
itself. For every Task Definition, Memory is required and CPU is not.
The next justification is backwards compatibility. If we're not careful
the next app deploy for all users will magically have some tight CPU
limits. If the default is wrong, we should change it, but probably with a
more careful migration strategy.
So what if the default was still 0, but your parameterization lands so you
and everyone else can start playing with tuning it?

GC health check params map essentially 1:1 with AWS', and so do Azure's probes except for the healthy_threshold concept (they do support the concept of unhealthy_threshold, which maps to Azure's numberOfProbes).

. I think @ddollar's example meant to say convox.health.endpoint=tcp:9000/foo as the label would already be under the process
. > My app takes a long time to boot so I add a single new label:

yaml
web:
  labels:
    - convox.health.path=/foo
  ports:
    - 80:5000

The default port protocol is currently tcp, but specifying path would implicitly change the port's protocol to http, which creates the relationship that the health check has some ownership of the path's protocol (ie. the protocol isn't independent anymore). I'm not sure if this would be a practical problem long-term, but something to note.
So is there opposition to adding healthy_threshold, unhealthy_threshold and interval as well? They're common to the 3 major cloud providers (except for azure not supporting healthy_threshold). As these health check params would be additional labels, they would be only specified for the power users
. They're decoupled afaik as well. @nzoschke are you implying that the health check proto would also be decoupled at the convox layer?
eg. taking the aforementioned example again:
web:
  labels:
    - convox.health.path=/foo
  ports:
    - 80:5000
- ELB ingress would be TCP:80
- Instance ingress would be TCP:5000
- Health check would be HTTP:5000/foo
But in this example:
web:
  labels:
    - convox.port.443.protocol=https
    - convox.health.path=/foo
    - convox.health.port=443
    - convox.health.timeout=120
  ports:
    - 443:5001
- ELB ingress would be HTTPS:443
- Instance ingress would be HTTPS:5001
- ~~Health check would be HTTPS:5001/foo~~ Health check would be HTTP:5001/foo

ianmalott:
@ddollar I got some clarification about Console and rack creation from @mattmanning:

When console installs a Rack it needs to store the Rack password so it can proxy API calls to it. I would assume David is asking if that will be broken by the Password NoEcho setting.
I'm guessing that since there's no --password option for the CLI installer that console fetches the password from CloudFormation after the install.
But would need to confirm.
If that's the case, we might want to have Console set the Password when it installs so it doesn't have to be fetched back.

Not sure how you'd want to proceed from here, but it seems like this is blocked by some Console and CLI changes.
. @ddollar: yep, only blocked on tests (and review of refactoring). Wasn't sure how to test a console-based rack installation, but I tested the following from the CLI:
- convox install --version <noecho-release> with --password and without
- convox rack update to a release with "NoEcho": "false" for Password param
- convox rack params set Password=foobarbaz
. @mwarkentin Thanks for the suggestion. @nzoschke has a doc on the way that describes how to set a new Rack API Key/Password: https://github.com/convox/site/pull/229
. @mwarkentin Thanks for the suggestion. @nzoschke has a doc on the way that describes how to set a new Rack API Key/Password: https://github.com/convox/site/pull/229

I don't know how to mock-toggle this in local tests, so in other words, the test output will be different locally (since we all have the AWS CLI installed) vs in Travis (which doesn't).. If these aren't unset, then they are present in the test suite environment. In order to test rack installs when no credentials are found, we need there to not be any credentials in the host environment.. I don't think there are any side effects (since we're executing bin/test, not sourcing it). The envvar isn't unset in the host environment permanently, only in the environment of the bash process that's running bin/test.
IMO in any test where an env var is accessed, we should set it explicitly, e.g. via:

Command: "FOO=bar convox install -h"
os.Setenv(...)
in the Env field of the ExecRun struct

...rather than relying on the environment of the user running the tests (with the obvious exceptions where we want the envvar to affect the test suite, like PKG and TEST).

But yeah, I am also trying to avoid running consul or similar tools.. I rewrote this to use actual time. At least I am hoping I did. The idea was to say, "now+configured interval".
(Disclaimer: I think I've never written that much Go before.). Here's where I am using it again — hopefully using time.After() correctly.. advance512:
Did this PR break envvar based linking when convox.balancer=false?. Would it not make sense to at least pass one of the created container's endpoint details?. @till 
I am pretty sure many others have been in this same boat, and in fact this might be the "killer feature" that prevents the project from being more popular among small startups and enthusiasts. I have 8 microservices in my project (and this will expand, a microservice per external system I interface into), but only one public access point. That is $140 that I would pay for no reason at all. Too bad, because I really like Convox otherwise.
Anyways, this missing feature might sadly be the reason I will stop using Convox and move to some sort of K8s based solution (like Rancher, Mantl or OpenShift - or many others).
For now, after deployment, I've created a small script that runs convox api get /apps/APP_NAME/processes, and updates DNS records in Route53 in which I've created an Private Zone (microservice.app_name.internal). Using convox env, I manually set the LINK env vars (MICROSERVICE_HOST=microservice.app_name.internal, MICROSERVICE_PORT=5000) and in the composition I set the ports to be: 5000:5000/tcp. 
Not very fun, definitely not production worthy, but it works.. @till  - that sounds great. Will have a look - though I think it is quickly nearing the same complexity as having a Consul cluster which is what I was trying to avoid.
Can you explain how you're using dd-agent? I don't see any code, just that you opened port 8125 UDP. . I tried using Consul and Linkerd. Let me just say it's very, very complex with Convox.
There are no guides or tutorials to be found. To create consul cluster, you'd need the addresses of all the Consule servers to bootstrap together (using TCP, not HTTP), and there is simply no easy way to do that in Convox, at least none that I could find. 
The best article I found suggests on the matter suggests to use Networking mode: Host in an ECS task definition to make things easier, but that means you're exiting the Convox world into "direct to ECS" world. You'd probably need to define DNS records that point at your Consul servers. Of course, each time you upgrade/modify your Rack, this will break. You could deploy the Consul servers on their own standalone EC2 instances. However, you'd still need Consul clients and Consul-Registrator on each ECS instance. Adding Linkerd for a network mesh puts you in the same problem as with the Consul servers, the need for hard-set peers that are enumerable, and not via ELBs.
Then there are issues with docker-compose vs local vs remote - e.g. you need networks in the docker-compose to make it work, and it indeed works with Docker Compose but not with convox start, you would need to create an exterior network. (In production, you'd need links. depends_on also works in some places and not others.. I don't remember exactly.)
I am sure it is doable, but after spending nearly 2 days trying to get this to work I eventually gave up. I've gone back to working, again, with multiple ELBs as is the Convox recommended way. I am actively waiting for the new ALB feature, but - if it doesn't arrive soon - I might have to migrate to Kubernetes. I was trying to avoid this due to not wanting to spend a lot of time on DevOps work at this point in the life of the project.. but I also can't spend hundreds of dollars per month for ELBs, either.. Will this help when using the overlay fs?.

swisslala: @ddollar if we default (or hardcode) convox as the name then we have to always override in the app code. For example Express or any other framework that uses connect inderneath would have to be aware of this since the default session id is 'connect.sid' in the headers. I'd advocate to make it free-form like aws allows.. If your app is managing sessions and controls the timeout then the ELB session management won't work.. @ddollar how so? If you are running multiple instances then they end up in the next round robin selected container. If your app is managing sessions and timeout then you may end up with ghosting issues especially when you sync that session to redis for example. It's basically telling the ELB to delegate session management. Otherwise people are forced to use other tools to fill in the gaps (which we are currently doing...).

slaskis:
allright, ready for another review!. Thanks for the yaml fix!
I've been trying to get my app running with this PR and I wanted to post some findings:
some are restricting me from using it:

resources does not seem to be accessible. they start and log properly but it seems an ingress is missing or something? even within the app it seems unable to find the resources. ~no workaround found yet for this.~ i think i actually found a workaround or two. within the cluster (as in env vars to other services) it can be accessed with <service>.convox-<app>.svc.cluster.local:<port> or resource-<resource>.convox-<app>.svc.cluster.local:<port>. and to access from outside the cluster you can use kubectl port-forward <service> <port> -n convox-<app>.
no code sync? or it tries but fails with sync add error: command terminated with exit code 1. 

some less important ones:

Service links does not work. I think this might actually be a non-feature, but it was very handy as the env vars remote and local got setup correctly without me having to look through CF outputs and thus it makes the transition slightly more cumbersome. links also don't expose any env vars, kubernetes seems to add some <service>_PORT and other magic env vars though. worked around by setting env vars manually. maybe convox-env could reassemble the env vars into link env vars? it seems like internal services must also similar ...cluster.local:<port>-hosts as resources and does not allow https.
healthchecks work now. this is obviously a good thing but previously it let me ignore that dynamodb-local does not respond to GET requests. worked around with a http proxy.
docker instability. i don't know why but docker kept crashing after a deploy. but seems to work better after switching to the stable channel.
default scale results in pods failing. i'm not sure what the limit is in kubernetes but it only managed to start 1 pod before failing with "insufficient memory" errors. worked around by setting scale for each service to cpu=64/mem=64.
it seems to have missed to uninstall the old router. so now the router logs just output the convox usage message on repeat
it seems old deployments are not removed when running convox deploy. this can cause the insufficient memory/cpu issue after a few deploys
. Thanks for the yaml fix!
